comments.commentBody:
Didn't St. Ronnie threaten to withhold highway funding unless Wisconsin raised the drinking age from 18 to 21?

Isn't your state being outperformed in every way by Minnesota and their liberal governor?

Doesn't the drug testing cost the taxpayers more than it saves?

Weren't you one of the first clowns bounced out of the Republican clown car?

I wonder how many times you used the word "I" in your article. It really is all about you, isnt it... You are waging war on the citizens of WI, especially the poor, homeless, and people of color. You should be ashamed of your union busting and the unconstitutional gerrrymandering by the Republican legislature that has disenfranchised citizens of this once great state. Now we are an example of how big Koch money can buy a state and its governor. Shame on you and your Republican cronies.
Thank you, New York Times, for taking us on a visit to Fantasy Land.
Sharon, I am right there with you.  I'm 65 and I just joined the ACLU.  I'm looking for more ways to be political active.  I am mad and I am afraid.  Walker and his cronies are clueless

Where were all you outraged folks on election day? Apparently there weren't enough of you voting to elect a candidate that doesn't stir such disgust. And don't hand me the popular vote argument. Our nation uses the electoral college and until that changes, popular vote is just a convenient salve for the loser's wounds.

I didn't vote for either the assumed choices - I stood strong and voted for a candidate that wasn't gifted with massive national media coverage or even allowed a place at the debates. My choice didn't even warrant a subversive campaign such as was directed at dear Bernie.

Just look at the venom spewed by protestors. It is of itself divisive and tone deaf. Petty comments criticizing the First Lady's choice of clothing, obsessive attention to every single tweet of stupidity. Hashtag-let's-go throw rocks and scream on a street corner accomplishes nothing. The Women's March was the same. It was about as focused as the Occupy movement. Lots of people with their own agendas who are unhappy about what they have in their own lives. And let's be honest - if some guy nicknamed those pink things "pussy hats" charges of sexism would have been rampant. At least the Civil Rights movement had a single point to make.

For decades votes have complained that Washington is broken and that they are tired of "business as usual". This is what a shake up looks like and for those whose favorite word is "transparency", well it's there in all its' 140 character glory!
Scott has more confidence in the survival of gerrymandered red states than the survival of the  Ryan-McConnell  machine. Hope he's right about the latter's  immanent collapse under Trump-Pence.
Joan, please include Connecticut in your list of blue states who would like to keep their taxes and not send them to the red states.
Well said!

Oh my goodness!  Where to begin?  This is "the high road"?  This is the guy who, during the Presidential Campaign,said something like, 'I'm getting out and most of you others should too so someone can beat this guy'?  (Not that it was incorrect.)  Drug testing for welfare folks? Beating down unions by dividing them into categories?  On and on.

Let's not forget about the night after passing Act 10 when the brave republican legislators boarded a bus and headed to the airport to travel to Washington to party with their billionaire friends!  The protests were peaceful.  There was no confrontation!
I thought we defeated that idea during the Civil War, but I think you are fight . Abraham Lincoln will be turning over in his grave

States right is a doctrine that allows convenient abuse.
If the right disagrees with a given state's position on anything, the doctrine of states rights does not apply.
Oh, well. I guess the New York Times feels obligated to give this cretin space. Understand, however, that when I see anything penned by him (rarely), I ignore it.
Brava, Joan; this New Yorker fully agrees.

And if you extend that logic then we might as well dismantle the concept of a United States. That is where Republicans have been pushing us all along anyway. They want their tax dollars to only benefit them and those they care about. That would exclude "those other people." And we know who they are. Each state then becomes its own country with our cooperative "national" defense being privatized to the Military Industrial Complex.

This country will never move forward with haters like Scott Walker and Trump trying to call the shots.  This country is far better than what you and your haters have to offer.  Enjoy your so called day in the sun.  Your days are numbered.

Hurray for you Walker!  So tired of all the vitriolic left wing insults.  Frankly, I'm surprised the NYT gave you a voice.  Too bad it falls on deaf ears that are so intent on their own message they fail to listen to anyone else.  One can only hope that they tire soon.

The Times gave him a "voice" BUT the People remind its readers how vilified this governor has been.

Who had to drop out first of all the GOP candidates? Walker!

Who was followed everywhere by protestors before he dropped out? Walker!

Who fells left out of this misbegotten DC sinking ship? Walker!

Whose underwater favorability is equal to trump? Walker?
I offer to pay for the gas or buy an sandwich or buy a bus ticket rather then give $ and  they disappear.

I think the Pope is a good person. That said, I find it rich that a man who lives in a palace, wears robes (and shoes) that cost thousands, has a staff of servants, cooks, chauffers, etc., is telling the general public - us chumps that actually WORK for a living to give to the poor. I think the majority of working people do, I do and I know others do as well. It's been my experience that the people who are the most generous with those less well off or homeless, are those who are working class or poor themselves, religion has nothing to do with it. You don't have to be religious to be a decent person and help a fellow human being that's down on their luck.
Just think of all the people that could be helped if the Vatican sold off all that gold and artwork and gave the money to the poor. And didn't Jesus have something to say about that too?
This pope is not the shoe and chauffeur guy the last one was.

I actually donate to pan-handlers without worry. The reasoning is simple: you never know.

The hard-core Calvinist believes they are the 'inherently depraved.' There is a difference between denominations. Catholicism is not the conservative religion many right-wingers in this country imagine it to be. Ross Douthat take notice.
You're missing the point entirely. It's about *choosing* to give your money to someone in need. I thought conservatives were all about private charity as opposed to public-sector charity.

Yes! I say the same thing to myself. This person needs it more than I do.

Same for tipping...when I'm trying to decide $3 or $4 tip - I always go the extra dollar because while (luckily) it doesn't make a huge difference to me, it might be the difference between a "good" or "great" tip, why not make someone feel good?!!

I like the idea of just giving.  I think if others are uncomfortable with supporting a substance abuse problem, that's ok too.  I think the important message is to be generous and generous of spirit.  Also, I like the ideas readers had about gift cards, Cliff bars, etc. -- ways to make someone's day a little easier.  There are certainly people that may not appeal to your sense of empathy out on the streets, but surely there are a few that do, if you look.

How about opening the bottomless Vatican bank coffers ?  Never any mention of this by the pope. Trillions are squirreled away in vatican vaults. Think of how the pope could virtually eradicate poverty.
The only obstacle between universal well-being and our world of misery is the Church hanging on to all that money--trillions in the vaults.
So many of the posts here comment on how they were taught by a parent to give.  I find this touching,and heartening.
